title: Invention of the printing press
description: Johannes Gutenberg prints 180 copies of a text ushering in the era of modern printing.

title: Industrial revolution
description: The industrial revolution had a great influence on the modern world, especially the economy and culture.

title: French Revolution
description: The French Revolution marked the origin of modern states.

title: Foundation of the School of Fine Arts in Paris
description: In this school the academicism was forged against which the vanguards would rebel.

title: First Photograph
description: Daguerre creates what is considered the first photograph. Photography brought important changes in visual culture and prompted modern artists to express their personal vision beyond the faithful representation of reality.

image.alt: Nicéphore Niépce, untitled. 1826. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public domain.

title: Modernism
description: Modern art is a process of transformation in which artists try to overcome traditional art forms to seek new forms of representation in art. The period of Modern Art can be located approximately between 1850 and 1960 and It comprises a multiplicity of artists and movements. This work by Manet was one of the first modern paintings and caused a great rejection in Paris.

image.alt: Édouard Manet. Olympia. 1863. Oil on canvas. Source: Wikimedia Foundation under the license CC BY 2.0.
image.caption: He was one of the forerunners of impressionism and modern painting. This work called Olympia, an ironic reference to Greek history, generated controversy for presenting a naked woman who apparently was a sex worker, defying the codes morals and the tradition of the female nude in art.

title: Olympia. Èdouard Manet
description: was one of the forerunners of impressionism and modern painting. This work called Olympia, an ironic reference to Greek history, generated controversy for presenting a nude woman who, apparently, is a sex worker; challenging moral codes and the tradition of the female nude in art.

title: The Mature Age Camille Claudel
description: was one of the forerunners of modern sculpture in opposition to the French Academy. In this work full of symbolism, her interest in themes other than those dictated by the classical canon is evidenced: the exaltation of beauty and perfection.

image.alt: Camille Claudel. The Old Age. 1899. Bronze. Source: Wikimedia Commons under the GNU free documentation license.
image.caption: Camille Claudel (Fère-en-Tardenois, France, 1864-1943) was one of the forerunners of modern sculpture in opposition to the French Academy. In this work full of symbolism her interest in themes other than those dictated by the classical canon: the exaltation of beauty and perfection.

title: The ladies of Avignon. Pablo Picasso
description: was probably the best known reference in modern painting, for challenging the figure and presenting images with marked alterations. This work introduced the deformation of bodies and abstractiongeometric n. as a new procedure in painting, which was later consolidated in cubism.

image.alt: Pablo Picasso. The young ladies of Avignon. 1907. Oil on canvas. Source: Wikimedia Commons under the license CC BY 2.0
image.caption: Pablo Picasso (Málaga, Spain, 1881-1973) was probably the best known reference in modern painting, for challenging the figure and presenting images with marked alterations. This work introduced the deformation of bodies and geometric abstraction as a new procedure in painting, which was later consolidated in cubism.

title: Fauvism
description: Such is their sense of independence, that the color of a line changes, so that in the same figure there may be parts of one color and parts of another.

title: Impressionism
description: This movement is characterized by the use of pure colors without mixing or hiding the brushstroke, giving prominence above all to light and color. I understand light and shadow from volumes such as the cylinder, the cone and the sphere.

title: Cubism
description: Cubism arose from the interest of painters in combining different perspectives, altering the shape of objects. They were inspired by prehistoric paintings.

title: Futurism
description: Futurism was named for its intention to break completely with the art of the past. It was inspired by industrial progress and an exaltation of the machine and the city.

title: Ready-made
description: Found objects stripped of their instrumental meaning. Artists explore the intellectual aspects of objects.

image.alt: El Sindicato Group. Ramiro Gómez, Carlos Restrepo, Alberto del Castillo, Efraín Arrieta, Aníbal Tobón and Guillermo Aragón. A-dinner with shoes. 1979. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: The experimental art group El Sindicato (Barranquilla, Colombia, 1973) was made up of various artists who worked on popular and socio-political concepts related to daily life with what was discarded by the system, and with those who were forgotten by it. This piece won the 1978 National Salon of Artists award, questioning the artistic institutionality, its materials, its codes and its power; both the title and the assembly with old and wasted shoes trigger reflections on social inequality.

title: German Expressionism
description: A pictorial movement that explored the power of color on an emotional and symbolic level.

title: Russian Constructivism
description: Constructivist forms are strongly linked to the materialist current of thought.

title: Dadaism
description: Artistic movement that emerged in Zurich (Switzerland) that explored chance and chaos as a creative form. It broke with traditional forms of art and combined different media in poetic and artistic actions that gave rise to performance.

title: Bauhaus
description: School that set important guidelines for modern and contemporary design and architecture

title: Geometric Abstraction
description: Term to refer to works that do not represent objects of the visible world but rather explore geometric shapes to create images.

image.alt: Amelia Peláez. Untitled, 1967. Source: MAMBO Collection.

title: Art Deco
description: A current of design and architecture with very diverse expressions that had its greatest commercial boom in the period between the First and Second World War.

title: Surrealism
description: Artistic movement that investigated the subconscious and dreams as a matter of artistic creation.

image.alt: Salvador Dalí. The Venus with the head of arrows. No date. Source: MAMBO Collection.

title: Social Realism
description: Realism was a movement that influenced writing and the arts in Latin America at the beginning of the 20th century

image.alt: Unknown author. Monument to the fighters of the October revolution. in Almaty, Kasakhstan. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public domain.

title: Gaitán publishes his thesis: Socialist Ideas in Colombia
description: Liberal revolutionary politician who was assassinated during his campaign for the Presidency of Colombia.

title: Massacre of the Bananeras
description: Massacre in which workers of the United Fruit Company, which owned large banana mills in Ciénaga, Magdalena, were murdered.

title: Origin of the Bachué group
description: This group arises from the work Bachué by Rómulo Rozo.

title: Alfonso López Pumarejo liberal president: The revolution in motion
description: Period that became known as the Second Liberal Republic in which the conservative hegemony was overthrown and the country entered a process of liberal modernization.

title: Creation of the popular graphic workshop in Mexico
description: Mexican popular graphics exerted an important influence on Latin American art at the beginning of the 20th century

image.alt: Jackson Pollock. Head. 1938-1941. Source: Wikimedia Commons licensed under CC BY 2.0.

title: Mariano Ospina Pérez, conservative president
description: Conservative President

title: First National Salon of Artists
description: Exhibition event inaugurated by President Eduardo Santos and Jorge Eliécer Gaitán, which is held annually as an exhibition platform for Colombian art.

title: The Hall of 26
description: One of the exhibition events wasndamentals in the history of Colombian art. It was organized by the artist Obregón.

title: El Bogotazo
description: Assassination of the liberal candidate Jorge Eliécer Gaitán, in the heart of Bogotá. His assassination started the Bogotazo; a period of social unrest in the city.

image.alt: Sady González. Tram on fire. 1948. Source: MAMBO Collection.

title: Face of Christ. Edgar Negret
description: Edgar Negret (Popayán, Colombia - 1920) was one of the most influential sculptors of the plastic arts in Colombia. He questioned the notions of the industrial and the natural by incorporating representative materials of modernity such as iron in his sculpture , aluminum and wood. In this work, an abstract representation of a figure of the Colombian religious culture can be appreciated.

image.alt: Edgar Negret. Face of Christ. 1949. Steel and Wood. Source: MAMBO Collection
image.caption: Edgar Negret (Popayán, Colombia, 1920-2012) He was one of the most influential sculptors of the plastic arts in Colombia. He questioned the notions of the industrial and the natural by incorporating representative materials of modernity such as iron, aluminum and wood in his sculpture. In this work, a abstract representation of a figure from Colombian religious culture.

title: Pop Art
description: Artistic movement that appropriates images and objects from consumer society.

image.alt: Andy Warhol. Campbell's soup cans. 1962. Special edition. 2015. Source: Wikimedia Commons under the Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported license.
image.caption: Andy Warhol (Pittsburg , United States, 1928-1987) is recognized as one of the pioneers of Pop Art in the United States. Warhol used products from the market to reflect on consumerism and originality in art. In this work, the artist copied a product box of mass consumption and produced reproductions of the packaging, questioning whether any object can be art and pointing out consumerism as the contemporary way of life.

title: Coup in Colombia
description: Rojas Pinilla to power. The newspaper El Sigio and the Salón Nacional in Colombia will close. Read more about Rojas Pinilla.

image.alt: Unknown author. Portrait of Gustavo Rojas Pinilla. S, f. Source: Wikimedia Commons under the CC BY SA 4.0 license.

title: Arrival of TV to Colombia
description: The arrival of television marked a transformation of visual culture in the country. In the words of Rojas Pinillas, television was the state, implying that it should serve institutional purposes. At this time there were strong restriction of press freedom such as the closure of the newspaper El Tiempo.

title: Creation of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia - FARC
description: Start of the armed conflict in Colombia.

title: Foundation of the Museum of Modern Art
description: Although the museum was founded in this year, it began its work in 1963 under the direction of Marta Traba. See link

image.alt: Instagram: @mambogota </br> Facebook: @fanmambogota </br> Twitter: @_mambogota </br> YouTube: Museum of Modern Art of Bogotá

title: Cae Rojas Pinilla
description: Vote of women in Colombia

title: Start andl National Front with Alberto Lleras Camargo liberal
description: Publication of the I Nadaísta Manifesto on toilet paper, Puerto Berrío, Medellín.

title: Installation
description: The artist Allan Kaprow coined the term installation to refer to a work he made at home filling a space with objects.

image.alt: Miguel Ángel Rojas. Grano, the time tunnel. 2018. Reconstruction that was presented in the Project Room in 1981. Coal dust, stones and sand. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: <href = '' target = 'blank'> Miguel Ángel Rojas </> (Bogotá, Colombia, 1946) is one of the most important artists in the country. The observation of the architecture of the 19th and 20th centuries has been one of the sources of inspiration for his work. In this installation the artist reconstructs the cement tiles on the floor of his grandparents' house in Girardot, the place where he lived his childhood, using charcoal and sand. The installation speaks of the subtlety of the memory through the material that fades throughout the exhibition.

title: Artists' performance in the Rejected Hall
description: Burning of coffins in downtown Bogota

title: Op Art
description: A visual style that seeks to deceive the human eye. To achieve that goal it often uses optical illusions or trompe l'oeil.

title: Fluxus
description: Dadaist-influenced anti-art movement that brought new media to the United States. Some of its most recognized artists were Nam June Paik and John Cage.

title: Postal Art
description: Use of transport and communication systems such as mail to create artistic works based on the exchange.

title: Scraps. Feliza Burztyn
description: Her sculptures in scrap metal and stainless steel waste recall the discussions of the 1960s and 1970s around the use of unconventional material, sexuality, abstraction and unusual montages.

title: Marta Traba, director of MAMBO
description: The renowned historian and art critic Marta Traba turns this initiative into reality and assumes the direction of the Museum. She raises the need to create an institution that disseminates the plastic arts.

title: End of the Algerian War of Independence.
description: End of the Algerian War of Independence

title: Violence. Alejandro Obregón.
description: Alejandro Obregón, (Barcelona, ​​Spain - 1920) lived in the country since he was 6 years old, was part of the Barranquilla Group and was a benchmark of modern and contemporary painting in Colombia. He created images that were debated between the figuration and abstraction (figurative expressionism), highlighting the expressive brushstrokes and the spot of color. This emblematic work is a reflection of his interest in denouncing the harshness of the national reality

image.alt: Alejandro Obregón. Violence. 1962. Obregón. Hernán Díaz. Source: MAMBO Collection
image.caption: Alejandro Obregón (Barcelona, ​​Spain, 1920-1992) lived in the country from the age of 6, he was part of the Barranquilla Group and was a benchmark of modern and contemporary painting in Colombia. He created images that debated between figuration and abstraction (figurative expressionism), which highlighted the expressive brushstrokes and the stain of color. This embleThis work is a reflection of his interest in denouncing the harshness of the national reality.

title: Student movements in Berkley, California
description: Birth of movements in defense of public education. Beginning of the countercultural and left-wing press and the Hippie movement

title: Glitter Boxes. Andy Warhol.
description: Andy Warhol (Pittsburg, United States - 1928) is recognized as one of the pioneers of Pop Art in the United States. Warhol used market products to reflect on consumerism and originality in art. In this work the artist copied the box of a mass consumer product and made a sculpture with 24 reproductions of the packaging, questioning whether any object can be art and pointing to consumerism as the contemporary way of life

title: Beatriz González - los suicidas del sisga
description: Beatriz González receives the second prize at the National Salon of Artists in 1965 for the realization of this painting

title: Minimalism
description: Less is more; artistic movement that seeks to reduce works to their most essential form

title: The Black Power movement is born in the US
description: Movement emerged to combat discrimination against the black population in the United States

title: What Dante didn't know, Beatriz loved birth control. Bernardo Salcedo.
description: Bernardo Salcedo (Bogotá, Colombia - 1939) was one of the pioneers of conceptual art in Colombia. He worked combining elements of painting, writing and sculpture, to generate questions about the socio-historical context. This work arises as tribute to the life of Dante Alighieri and his muse Beatriz Portinari, with whom he never consummated his love. This work was awarded for reflecting the new proposals of conceptual art: the use of minimalist volumes and irony in his name

title: Shooting of Che Guevara in Bolivia
description: Execution of Che Guevara in Bolivia. One of the Latin American revolutionary icons falls

title: Extra-parliamentary movement
description: Student demonstrations in West Germany

title: Women's Liberation Movement
description: The first organizations of the Women's Liberation Movement were formed in major cities such as Berkeley, Boston, Chicago, New York and Toronto

title: Gloria Zea assumes the management of MAMBO.
description: Zea assumes the leadership after Marta Traba's exile due to her opposition to the measures of the National Government

title: May 68
description: Chain of protests that took place in France

title: Exhibition 'Environmental Spaces' at MAMBO
description: It marked the beginning of the installation in the country as it was one of the first samples to integrate the architectural space and the experience of the public, to art

title: Art and Language Group
description: Artists begin to be interested in language as raw material, giving rise to conceptual art

title: Prague Spring
description: Repression of the USSR in Czechoslovakia

title: Abbie Hoffman and the Chicago Seven
description: Accused of charges of conspiracy, incitement to riot, and other charges related to the violent protests

title: The term 'counterculture' appears
description: The term appears in 1968, in a book by the historian Theodore Roszak to refer to the beat generation, the hippie movement, the sexual revolution and the American pacifist movements

title: Shower curtains. Óscar Muñoz.
description: Oscar Muñoz (Popayán, Colombia - 1951) is an artist who has explored different media and materials, including video and photography to make proposals that incorporate time and space in drawing. In this series, the artist makes a comment on intimacy and the absence of bodies from a series of shower curtains with human silhouettes drawn on them.

image.alt: Óscar Muñoz. Shower curtains. 1986. Acrylic on plastic. Source: MAMBO Collection
image.caption: Oscar Muñoz (Popayán, Colombia, 1951) is an artist who has explored different media and materials, including video and photography to make proposals that incorporate time and space in the drawing. In this series of shower curtains with human silhouettes drawn on them, the artist makes a comment about the intimacy and the absence of bodies.

title: Salcedo and Barrios cover their works in the National Hall with black fabrics
description: Salcedo and Barrios cover their works in the National Hall with black fabrics in protest

title: Land Art
description: Artistic movement based on the relationship between the artist, the landscape and the elements it contains. A rebellious movement towards the work locked up in museums and galleries

title: Woodstock Festival.
description: Famous festival that lasted several days in which the most important musicians of Rock'n Roll met, such as Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin and Santana, among others. This festival was a milestone in the hippie movement. I'm from the Woodstock nation, it's a state of mind.

img.alt: Mark Goff. Woodstock Festival Opening Ceremony. 1969. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public domain.

title: Paris Conference
description: Peace agreement with Vietnam. The war ends with the withdrawal of US troops.

title: LGBT liberation movement
description: LGBT liberation movement in NYC after the Stonewall riots

title: Arte Povera
description: He uses discarded materials in his works such as metal fragments, pieces of glass, earthenware, etc.

title: Hyperrealism
description: Artistic movement that takes realism to its limits; where painting and photography are confused.

title: Head of Lleras
description: The inauguration of a National Salon of Artists is flooded because of the work of Antonio Caro Cabeza by Carlos Lleras in salt.

title: Insertions in Ideological Circuits. Cildo Meireles
description: Cildo Meireles (Rio de Janeiro, Brazil - 1948) is recognized for his contributions to Latin American conceptual art. In this series, the artist appropriates objects of everyday use and consumption, such as Coca Cola bottles, which intervenes with the phrase “Yankees go home” to reinsert them in the market.

image.alt: Cildo Meireles. Zero cruzeiro. 1974. Lithography. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Cildo Meireles (Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 1948) is a renowned artist for his contributions to Latin American conceptual art through works made from the analysis of Latin American economic and political systems. In this series that we see he recreates a series of counterfeit bills to reflect on capital, power and exploitation.

title: Almost still life. Beatriz González.
description: Beatriz González (Bucaramanga, Colombia - 1938) is one of the most recognized artists in Colombia, her work has explored the limits between painting and sculpture, using popular culture images in everyday objects to communicate her reflections on the Colombian context and the problems associated with conflict, gender and landscape. In this work, the artist intervenes a wooden bed with a religious image.

image.alt: Beatriz González. Almost still life. 1970. Synthetic enamel on metal sheet assembled in furniture. Source: MAMBO Collection
image.caption: Beatriz González (Bucaramanga, Colombia, 1938 ) is one of the most recognized artists in Colombia, her work has explored the limits between painting and sculpture, using images from popular culture in everyday objects to communicate her reflections on the Colombian context and the problems associated with conflict, gender and the landscape. In this work, the artist intervenes a wooden bed with a religious image.

title: Pan American Exhibition of Graphic Arts
description: Made in Cali, Colombia.

title: Greenpeace
description: Birth of the environmental organization Greenpeace.

title: Popular prints
description: Álvaro Barrios deliberately appropriated images from popular tradition, such as the martyred body of San Sebastián and endowed them with unexpected content

title: Cuja, Feliza Bursztyn.
description: Feliza Burstyn (Bogotá, Colombia - 1933) is considered the precursor of the installation in Colombia. A controversial and transgressive sculptor who was able to go against the established order in art, using unconventional materials such as scrap metal. iron, stainless steel waste and motors to make his sculptural compositions. Similarly, he became interested in including movement and sound in his works, with his series of beds - sculptures covered with shiny fabrics that suggest bodies in motion during their sexual acts. Feliza sought to stage an intimate and private moment to bring it out to the public, creating an environment of eroticism that envelops the viewer in an emotional and sensorial experience.

image.alt: Feliza Bursztyn. Cuja. 1972. Source: MAMBO Collection
image.caption: <a href 1963'https://cerosetenta.uniandes.edu.co/feliza-bursztyn-en-un-pais-de-machistas-hagase-la-loca/' target='blank'> Feliza, stainless steel waste and motors to make her sculptural compositions.In the same way, she was interested in including movement and sound in her works; in her series of beds-sculptures covered with shiny fabrics, bodies in movement are suggested during their sexual acts.

title: Avianca Building Fire
description: Before the accident this building was the tallest in South America.

title: Carlos Caicedo Works
description: The reporter who spoke with images.

image.alt: Carlos Caicedo. Bogotá, 1975. Source: MAMBO Collection.

title: A Colombian History by Esso. Nirma zarate and Diego arango
description: Nirma Zárate (Bogotá, 1936-1999) and Diego Arango (Medellín, 1946) were founders of Taller 4 Rojo, one of the most important artistic groups for graphic and critical production in the country. reflects his interest in denouncing imperialism with suggestive and symbolic images.

image.alt: Nirma Zárate and Diego Arango. Colombian History by Esso. 1973. Serigraph. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Nirma Zárate (Bogotá, 1936-1999 ) and Diego Arango (Medellín, 1946) were founders of Taller 4 Rojo < / a>, one of the most important artistic groups for graphic and critical production in the country. This work reflects its interest in denouncing imperialism with suggestive and symbolic images.

title: End of the National Front
description: The National Front ends with the conservative Misael Pastrana

title: Origin of the M-19
description: This Colombian urban guerrilla organization arises as a result of the fraud in the presidential elections of April 19, 1970, in which Misael Pastrana was elected. Read more at:

title: Landscape, from the Mental Sheet series. Gustavo Sorzano
description: Gustavo Sorzano (Bucaramanga, Colombia - 1944) was interested in actively involving the viewer. In this work he reproduces in serigraphy and offset printing, art icons such as the Mona Lisa, modifying its color, format and technique to give it a popular character, leaving a space 9 to be intervenedor by the viewer.

image.alt: Gustavo Sorzano. Landscape, from the series Mental scores, momentum 43 participation event. 1974. Offset printing. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Gustavo Sorzano (Bucaramanga, Colombia, 1944) was interested in actively involving the viewer . In this work reproduces in serigraphy and in offset printing icons of art like the Mona Lisa, modifying its color, format and technique to give it a popular character, leaving a blank space for the viewer to intervene.

title: Athens Salons begin
description: Space for the avant-garde practices of the time in the country.

title: Colombia - Cocacola
description: Antonio Caro

image.alt: Antonio Caro. Colombia Coca-Cola. 1976. Lithography. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Antonio Caro (Bogotá , Colombia, 1950) is one of the most important conceptual artists in Colombia. < / a> His works reflect a high political and social content expressed through humor and irony. Caro contradicted the artistic parameters of the time by using popular images, materials and unconventional techniques. This lithograph is one of the most important works of the conceptual art, since in it the artist appropriates the Coca-Cola logo to generate a reflection on imperialism.

title: The magazine 'Arte en Colombia' is founded
description: With a female nude by the artist Darío Morales on the cover, the only magazine specialized in art that exists in Colombia began to circulate.

title: Anti-nuclear marches
description: They were made in England, Germany and the USA: it arises in response to the dangerous use, development and expansion of nuclear technology for warfare.

title: Sun Tunnels. Nancy Holt
description: Nancy Holt (Worcester, United States - 1938) was one of the forerunners in proposing new ways of perceiving the landscape through transdisciplinary works. In this characteristic work of Land Art and Minimalism she installed a series of tunnels of cement with holes in a plain. Every December 21, winter solstice, the sun aligns itself with the tunnels reflecting inside the tunnel.

image.alt: Nancy Holt. Sun Tunnels. 1976. Leaky cement pipes. Source: Wikimedia Commons licensed under C.C. 2.0.
image.caption: Nancy Holt ( Worcester, United States, 1938-2014) was one of the precursors of new ways of perceiving the landscape through transdisciplinary works.In this characteristic work of Land Art and Minimalism he installed a series of cement tunnels with holes in a plain. Every December 21, winter solstice, the sun aligns itself with the tunnels by reflecting inside the tunnel.

title: Paper and Pencil. Jonier Marín.
description: Jonier Marín (Algeria, Colombia - 1946) questions the traditional processes of art, and with her proposal she generates a work that confronts us with the question of What is art and who validates it?' Without wasting time I proposed to artists I met while traveling, to draw anything in pencil on a sheet of paper, and attach their portrait to the drawing, thus validating the work.' Jonier Marín.

image.alt: Jonier Marín. Paper and Pencil. 1976. Source: MAMBO Collection
image.caption:
Jonier Marín (Algeria, Colombia, 1946) questions the traditional processes of art, and with his proposal he generates a work that raises the question: what is art and who validates it?

'Without wasting time I proposed to artists I met while traveling, to draw in pencil on any sheet of paper. thing, and attach his portrait to the drawing, thus validating the work '. Jonier Marín.

title: Turbay Ayala liberal president
description: His presidential term was from August 7, 1978 - August 7, 1982

title: 'A-la-cena con Zapatos' Wins the first prize at the National Salon of Artists
description: The awards for the works of El Sindicato 'Alacena con zapatos' and Ana Mercedes Hoyos 'Atmosphere', were the first recognition of conceptual art in Colombia

image.alt: El Sindicato Group. Ramiro Gómez, Carlos Restrepo, Alberto del Castillo, Efraín Arrieta, Aníbal Tobón and Guillermo Aragón. A-dinner with shoes. 1979. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: The experimental art group El Sindicato (Barranquilla, Colombia, 1973) was made up of various artists who worked on popular and socio-political concepts related to daily life with what was discarded by the system, and with those who were forgotten by it. This piece won the 1978 National Salon of Artists award, questioning the artistic institutionality, its materials, its codes and its power; both the title and the assembly with old and wasted shoes trigger reflections on social inequality.

title: Construction of the current MAMBO headquarters begins
description: Photograph of Oscar Monsalve

image.alt: 1978. Construction of the current headquarters of the Museum. Photograph of Oscar Monsalve

title: The Great Plexi. Álvaro Barrios.
description: Álvaro Barrios (Cartagena, Colombia - 1945) is an artist from the Colombian Caribbean, who from a young age expressed his interest in conceptualism, making ready-mades and appropriations of popular graphics. In this work, the artist makes reference to Marcel Duchamp's work, The Large Glass, but it uses Plexiglas and incorporates a series of letters, notes and photographs that were part of an exchange made with a friend of his.

image.alt: Álvaro Barrios. The Great Plexi. 1979. Source: MAMBO Collection
image.caption: Álvaro Barrios (Cartagena, Colombia, 1945) is an artist from the Colombian Caribbean who from a young age expressed his interest in conceptualism, making ready-mades and appropriations of popular graphics. In this work, the artist refers to the work of Marcel Duchamp; Barrios it uses plexiglass and incorporates a series of letters, notes and photographs that were part of an exchange made with a friend of his.

title: Paper Moon, Bicycle Shirt, Chicago Lover, Frog Rider. Adolfo Bernal
description: Adolfo Bernal (Medellín, 1954) is an artist who addresses the urban context and its interactions. He studied typographies meticulously, turning words into images; this work installed in public space proposes posters with words without an apparent relationship , opening possibilities of interpretation in each passerby.

image.alt: Paper Moon, Bicycle Shirt, Chicago Lover, Rana Frog. Adolfo Bernal 1979. Offset Printing. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Adolfo Bernal. (Medellín, 1954) is a artist who addresses the urban context and its interactions. He studied typographies meticulously, turning words into images. This work installed in public space proposes posters with words without a relationship between them.rent, which opens up interpretation possibilities for each passerby.

title: Seizure of the Dominican Republic embassy by the M-19
description: Kidnapping of diplomats from many countries at a celebration commemorating the independence of the Dominican Republic

title: Dreams with M. Duchamp
description: Álvaro Barrios, using the mass media, managed to make and distribute thousands of copies of his work and spread the works of art to a public that does not have access to unique pieces.

title: Trap. Fernando Cepeda
description: Fernando Cepeda (nd) made MAMBO his home for two weeks. He built a kind of cell on the first floor of the Museum, exposing his private life to all visitors. Photographer Oscar Monsalve periodically recorded the artist's stay in the Museum while brushing his teeth, before sleeping, his reading hours, etc. These photographs were pasted on a wall outside the cell and in this way the visitors could see the day to

image.alt: Fernando Cepeda. Trap. 1980. Photographic Record of Oscar Monsalve. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Fernando Cepeda (sf) made MAMBO his home for two weeks. Cepeda built a kind of cell on the first floor of the Museum, exposing his private life to all visitors. Photographer Oscar Monsalve periodically recorded the artist's stay in the Museum while brushing his teeth, before sleeping, during his reading hours, etc. These photographs were pasted on a wall outside the cell and in this way the visitors could see the day-to-day of the artist.

title: First Latin American Colloquium on non-object art
description: Critics and academics debated non-objectualism for four days in Medellín

title: Inauguration of the Museum of Modern Art in Medellín.
description: It has been a living, urban and current museum, a space for meeting, knowledge and enjoyment in which contemporary and diverse artistic and cultural manifestations have a place.

title: Anonymous 1. Maria Evelia Marmolejo
description: Maria Evelia Marmolejo (Pradera, Colombia - 1958) is an artist who since the 80's has used her body as a tool for creating and communicating her denunciations against oppression and violence. Her marked feminist, environmentalist and anti Militarist has defined his works as radicals and activists.

image.alt: María Evelia Marmolejo. Anonymous 1. 1981. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Maria Evelia Marmolejo (Pradera, Colombia, 1958) is an artist who since the 1980s has used her body as a tool for creating and communicating her denunciations against oppression and violence. Her marked feminist, environmentalist character and antimilitarist has defined his works as radicals and activists.

title: Grano, the time tunnel. Miguel Ángel Rojas.
description: Miguel Ángel Rojas (Bogotá, Colombia - 1946) is one of the most important artists in the country. The observation of 19th and 20th century architecture has been one of the sources of inspiration for his work. In this installation , the artist reconstructs (with charcoal and sand) the cement tiles on the floor of his grandparents' house in Girardot, the place where he lived his childhood. The installation speaks of the subtlety of memory through the material that fades throughout of the exhibition.

image.alt: Miguel Ángel Rojas. Grain. 1975 MAMBO Collection

title: Betancur conservative president.
description: Presidential term: August 7, 1982 - August 7, 1986

title: Rose of the Winds Series. Rosa Navarro.
description: Rosa Navarro (Barranquilla, Colombia - 1955) was a conceptual artist interested in language. Her work starts from the exploration of her name as the central theme of her work. This series of self-portraits is a sample of the game of meanings with the word rose

image.alt: Rosa Navarro. Wind Rose series. Color photography. 1983. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: (Barranquilla, Colombia, 1955) is a conceptual artist interested in the. language, her work starts from the exploration of her name as the central theme of her work. This series of self-portraits is a sample of the play of meanings with the word rose.

title: From the interior series. Fernell Franco
description: Fernell Franco (Versalles, Colombia - 1942) develops his work mainly around the urban life of Cali in the 70's. In the city he captures images of the streets, prostitutes, billiards, demolitions, houses, festivals and bicycles. In this series in particular, he records interior spaces of places where he lived and worked through analog photography in 9 9 and then intervenes manually with color

image.alt: Interior series (1983) by Fernell Franco Museum of Modern Art of Bogotá. MAMBO

title: End of the Cold War
description: The fall of the Berlin Wall marked the fall of the U.S.S.R. and the end of the Cold War

image.alt: Unknown author. Berlin Wall photograph. 1989. Source: Wikimedia Commons < / a> under the GNU license.

title: Your Body is a Battleground. Barbara Kruger.
description: Barbara Kruger (New Jersey, United States - 1945) reflected on the notions of the body, gender and identity through advertising images with critical messages. Her style was characterized by the use of photographs in 9 and 9 intervened with text. In this work, she reflects on violence against the female body, understanding it as the battlefield of multiple political, social and cultural conflicts present in society

title: Body Paint
description: The body is intervened as a plastic material

title: Digital Art
description: Use of digital tools such as sensors, video projections, lights, etc

title: Net Art
description: Use the internet as a platform for artistic creation

title: Relational Art
description: Interactions between the viewer and the work

title: Crown for a chibcha princess. Maria Fernanda Cardoso.
description: Maria Fernanda Cardoso (Bogotá, Colombia - 1963) is a multidisciplinary artist who has investigated nature through photography, sculpture and performance. Her work has taken her to important stages such as the Venice Biennale. In this work, the artist makes a crown with stuffed lizards.

image.alt: Maria Fernanda Cardoso. Crown for a chibcha princess. Lizards and Metal. 1990. Source: MAMBO Collection
image.caption: Maria Fernanda Cardoso (Bogotá, Colombia, 1963) is a multidisciplinary artist who has investigated nature through photography, sculpture and performance. Her work has taken her to important stages such as the Venice Biennale. This work is a crown of stuffed lizards.

title: One thing is one thing and another is another thing. Maria Teresa Hincapié
description: This work won the award at the National Salon of Artists, being the first official recognition of performance in Colombia

title: The physical impossibility of death in the mind of the living. Damien Hirst.
description: Damien Hirst (Bristol, United Kingdom - 1965) is one of the most sought-after contemporary artists on the art market. He makes this series of sculptures with animals dissected in formaldehyde to question the public about the ephemeral and the limits between life and death

image.alt: Damien Hirst. The physical impossibility of death in the mind of the living. 1991. Source: Wikimedia Commons under the license Generic Creative Commons Attribution / Share -Same 3.0.
image.caption: <a href='http://velvet-mag.lat/2019/07/04/controversia-demuerte-y-colores-damien-hirst/' target='blank'> Damien Hirst </ a > (Bristol, United Kingdom, 1965) is one of the most sought-after contemporary artists on the art market, creating this series of sculptures with animals dissected in formaldehyde to question the public about the ephemeral and the limits between life and death.

title: My hands are my heart. Gabriel Orozco.
description: Gabriel Orozco (Veracruz, Mexico - 1962) is an artist who since the 90's has explored the limits of sculpture, through multiple concepts and media. In this work, he takes a photograph of an action with a sculptural result, which reflects on the human body

title: Constituent Assembly
description: Declaration of the new constitution in Colombia that decrees the Social State of Law

image.alt: Photograph of a publication of the Colombian constitution. The book was printed in December 1991, in the workshops of IMPREANDES, SA, Bogotá, Colombia. 2019. Source: Wikimedia Commons under license CC BY SA 3.0

title: The Master of Celán. Elías Heim.
description: Elías Heim (Cali, Colombia - 1966) is recognized for his on-site installations, which incorporate facts and situations from the assembly site. Heim's works blend with architecture using industrial technologies and materials, such as this work in which he draws a skeleton with aluminum grilles connected to an air conditioner

image.alt: Elías Heim. The Master of Celán. 1992. Air conditioning duct, aluminum grilles and refrigeration unit. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Elías Heim (Cali, Colombia, 1966) is recognized for his on-site installations, which incorporate facts and situations from the mounting location. Heim's works blend with architecture using industrial technologies and materials, such as this work in which he draws a skull with aluminum grilles connected to an air conditioner.

title: Electronic Superhighway: Continental U.S., Nam June Paik.
description: Video installation of the artist representing Fluxus

title: Who gives more? Fernando Arias
description: Fernando Arias (Armenia, Colombia - 1963) works around multiple socio-political problems such as the exploitation of resources, HIV and the armed conflict. This work is the photographic record of a tattoo of his signature on his skin , which was later sold at auction questioning art and the body as consumer objects

image.alt: Fernando Cepeda. Who gives more? 1997. Source: Mambo Collection.
image.caption: Fernando Cepeda (sf) made MAMBO his home for two weeks. Cepeda built a kind of cell on the first floor of the Museum, exposing his private life to all visitors. Photographer Oscar Monsalve periodically recorded the artist's stay in the Museum while brushing his teeth, before sleeping, during his reading hours, etc. These photographs were pasted on a wall outside the cell and in this way the visitors could see the day-to-day of the artist.

title: Points obsession. Yayoi Kusama.
description: Yayoi Kusama (Matsumoto, Japan - 1929) is an artist who builds large environments with textures, spots and colors, offering an immersive experience in which the sensation of space and the body change completely. Her artistic installations are spaces. Amazing

image.alt: Yayoi Kusama. Obsession points. 1999. Source: Wikimedia Commons under the CC BY 2.0 license.
image.caption: Yayoi Kusama (Matsumoto, Japan, 1929) is an artist who builds large environments with textures, stains and colors offering an immersive experience in which the sensation of space and the body change completely. Her artistic installations are amazing spaces.

title: Urban Art
description: Art that intervenes in the public space through techniques such as graffiti, muralism, posters, and performance

image.alt: Banksy. Lovers. 2006. Source: Wikimedia Commons under the CC BY 2.0 license.
image.caption: Banksy (Bristol, UK, 1974) is the nickname of one of the best-known artists of urban art. Since Pop Art's foray into graphic and advertising media, artistic practices in urban space have acquired an important role. In this work Banksy recreates a scene funny, using the wall as a narrative surface in public space.

title: Virtual Art
description: Use of virtual and expanded reality tools in art

title: Video Performance
description: Performance through audiovisual media

title: Darkytown Rebellion. Kara Walker.
description: Kara Walker (Stockton, United States - 1969) is an Afro artist who has dabbled in drawing, collage, installation and film since the 1960s. Her work isset in the pre-American civil war era and through the use of characters built with silhouettes, it questions the notions of race, gender and identity. This work is an installation that reconstructs the episodes of rebellion of African American slaves during the civil war.

title: Natalia Rivera
description: Natalia Rivera (Bogotá, 1953) uses everyday objects to create installations. In this work she reconstructs a scene from a beauty reign with three pairs of heels, questioning the viewer about the stereotypes of the female body

image.alt: Natalia Rivera. The finalists. 1980. Source: MAMBO Collection. Natalia Rivera (Bogotá, 1953) uses everyday objects to make installations. In this work she reconstructs a scene from a beauty reign with pairs of heels, questioning the viewer on the stereotypes of the female body.
image.caption: Natalia Rivera (Bogotá, 1953) uses everyday objects to make installations. In this work she reconstructs a scene from a beauty reign with pairs of heels , questioning the viewer about the stereotypes of the female body.

title: Detection 1. Ana Adarve
description: Ana Adarve (Bogotá, Colombia - 1976) is a Colombian artist who has stood out in recent years for her work with digital photography. She carries out a meticulous job of photomontage with which she composes large-format panoramic photographs of the urban space

image.alt: Ana Adarve. Detection 1. 2005. Digital photography. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Ana Adarve (Bogotá, Colombia, 1976) is a Colombian artist who has outstanding in recent years for his work with digital photography. He does a meticulous photomontage job with which he composes large-format panoramic photographs of urban space.

title: Maid in London. Banksy.
description: Banksy (Bristol, United Kingdom - 1974) is the nickname of one of the best-known artists of urban art. From the incursion of Pop Art in graphic and advertising media, artistic practices in urban space have acquired an important role. In this work Banksy makes a critical comment on social inequality and the way in which society hides its problems

title: Requiem N.N. Juan Manuel Echavarría
description: Juan Manuel Echavarría (Medellín, Colombia - 1947) is an artist who since the 90's explores the different territories of the country in search of the trace of the armed conflict. Through photography and video, he records scenarios where they happened acts of violence to preserve their memory and generate a poetic look at reality. In this work, he photographed the tombstones of a cemetery on the banks of the Magdalena River where the bodies of the NN dumped downstream have been buried

image.alt: Juan Manuel Echavarría. Requiem NN. 2006-2015. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Juan Manuel Echavarría (Medellín, Colombia, 1947) is an artist who has been exploring the different territories of the country in search of the trace of the armed conflict since the 1990s, through photography and video recording scenes where acts of violence occurred to preserve his memory and generate a poetic view of reality. This work are photographs of the tombstones of a cemetery on the banks of the Magdalena River where the bodies of the NN dumped downstream have been buried.

title: Environmental Spaces II. Tribute to Marta Traba. Santiago Cárdenas.
description: Santiago Cárdenas (Bogotá, Colombia - 1937) is recognized as an exponent of contemporary painting for returning to and deepening realism. In this installation, the artist uses painting to recreate unreal spaces that play with theviewer perception. This work was made for the first time in the exhibition Espacios Ambientales at the Museum of Modern Art of Bogotá - MAMBO in 1968

image.alt: Santiago Cárdenas. Environmental Spaces II, Tribute to Marta Traba. 2006. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Santiago Cárdenas (Bogotá, Colombia, 1937) is recognized as an exponent of contemporary painting for taking up and deepening realism. In this installation , the artist uses painting to recreate unreal spaces that play with the perception of the viewer. This work was made for the first time in the exhibition Espacios Ambientales del MAMBO in 1968.

title: Forgetting Arena. Mario Opazo
description: Mario Opazo (Tomé, Chile - 1969) emigrated as a result of the dictatorship to Colombia, where he has received several awards for his artistic work. His work includes installations, videos, performance and drawings, with which he creates poetic works as acts of resistance that allude to memory and displacement. In this action carried out on a beach in Magdalena Medio, his interest in video-performance is evidenced

image.alt: Forgetting Arena. Mario Opazo. 2007. Source: Opazo (s. f). Vimeo.
image.caption: Mario Opazo (Tomé, Chile, 1969) He emigrated as a consequence of the dictatorship to Colombia. He has received several awards for his artistic work. His work includes installations, videos, performances and drawings, with which he creates poetic works as acts of resistance that allude to memory and displacement. In this action carried out on a beach in Magdalena Medio, it is evident his interest in video-performance.

title: Post Internet
description: Works derived from the Internet or their effects on aesthetics, culture and society. More information at:

title: Generative Art
description: It is one that partially or in its entirety, has been created with the use of an autonomous system. Explore these references

title: The artist is present. Marina Abrámovic
description: Marina Abramovic (Belgrade, Serbia - 1946) is an artist known for being a forerunner of performance. Throughout her life she proposed different artistic actions that tended to involve the public, questioning the limits between art and life. In this work, he proposes a very simple action: look the viewer in the eye for as long as he or she decides. This performance invites the public to participate and generates an intimate and deep space in the museum, based on silence and gaze

image.alt: Marina Abramovic. The artist is present. 2010 . Source: Wikimedia Commons under the CC BY-SA 3.0 license.
image.caption: Marina Abramovic (Belgrade, Serbia, 1946) is an artist known for being a forerunner of performance, and throughout her life she proposed different artistic actions that tended to involve the public, questioning the limits between art and life. This work proposes a very simple action: look into the viewer's eyes for as long as he or she decides. This performance invites the public to participate through silence and gaze, creating an intimate and deep space in the museum.

title: Roses and thorns. Catalina Mejía
description: Catalina Mejía (Bogotá, Colombia - 1962) is a representative artist of contemporary painting in Colombia. She has experimented with collage proposing enigmatic images with nostalgic atmospheres, where the figurative and the abstract inhabit through the management of the light. In this work the simpleillez and sensitivity of the artist who in a subtle way transmits a deep and dramatic feeling

image.alt: Catalina Mejía. Roses and thorns. 2011. Mixed on canvas. Source: MAMBO Collection.
image.caption: Catalina Mejía (Bogotá, Colombia, 1962 ) is a representative artist of contemporary painting in Colombia. She has experimented with collage, proposing enigmatic images with nostalgic atmospheres through the use of light. This work shows the simplicity and sensitivity of the artist, between the figurative and the The abstract gives us a deep and dramatic feeling.

title: Claudia Hakim assumes the management of MAMBO
description: The artist assumed the leadership with a new team that proposes a Museum with all citizens and with various proposals for curatorship, museography and education.

image.alt: Claudia Hakim, director of MAMBO

title: Signing of the peace agreement with the FARC.
description: End of a conflict of more than 50 years

image.alt: Head of State participates in the Peace Signing ceremony between the Government of Colombia and the FARC EP Government of Chile. 2016. Source: Wikiveimedia Commons under license 'target =' blank '> CC BY 2.0

title: Labyrinth Ritual. Gilles Charalmbos.
description: Gilles Charalambos (France - 1958) has lived in Colombia since 1973 where he has been one of the forerunners of video art. He has worked since the late 70's in electronic arts, performance, and television, among others. This work is a journey through different sensory labyrinths that explores sounds and visual textures
